Title: Individualized End-Inspiratory Pause in Prone Spinal Surgery: A Randomized Controlled Trial

Background: The prone position in spinal surgery can decrease lung compliance and increase airway pressure. This study evaluated the effect of individualized end-inspiratory pause (EIP) guided by driving pressure on respiratory mechanics during prone spinal surgery.

Methods: This randomized controlled trial was conducted from August to October 2023 at a single hospital. Patients scheduled for elective prone spinal surgery were randomly assigned to either a study group, receiving individualized EIP, or a control group, receiving a fixed EIP (10% of total inspiratory time). The primary outcome was respiratory system compliance (C_RS) measured intraoperatively. Randomization was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed in sealed envelopes. Outcome assessors, data collectors, and patients were blinded to group allocation.

Results: Thirty-eight patients were randomized, with 18 in each group analyzed. The study group showed a significant increase in C_RS (mean difference = 6 mL·cmH2O−1, p < 0.05) and improved oxygenation compared to the control group. The individualized EIP also significantly decreased plateau pressure and driving pressure (p < 0.05). No postoperative pulmonary complications were observed in either group.

Interpretation: Individualized EIP guided by driving pressure effectively optimized pulmonary compliance and improved oxygenation during prone spinal surgery. This ventilation strategy may enhance respiratory mechanics and reduce the risk of postoperative pulmonary complications.

Trial registration: ChiCTR2300074398

Funding: Not specified.
